title_review: Excellent food and the friendliest, warmest service
review_preview: My mom and I ate here three times during the week we spent in Madrid, twice for dinner and once for lunch.The tomato soup we had the first night we ate dinner there was the best tomato soup I have ever had. Yum! The...
review_full: My mom and I ate here three times during the week we spent in Madrid, twice for dinner and once for lunch. The tomato soup we had the first night we ate dinner there was the best tomato soup I have ever had. Yum! The whole meal was excellent. Crispy mushroom croquettes were one highlight, a delightfully crispy outside covering a super-creamy mushroom filling. Prices were reasonable for dinner and downright cheap for lunch (6.5 Euro for appetizer, entree, dessert, and lemonade). The servers were fantastic, treating us as dear friends. (Even got a nice hug from David when we unexpectedly ran into him in Puerta del Sol our last day in Madrid). My mom and I both felt that this was the best vegetarian food we had in Madrid.

The food was fantastic, even my agressively carnivorous son was impressed by the chili con "carne". All the dishes were very tasty, with a superb dressing on the salad and great sauce with the courgette lasagne. The dessert list was very imaginatice'a lonng way from the typical flan, rice etc The decor is interesting with some nice touches like the cottonreel lampshade. The service was very friendly and quite efficient. The wine list was restricted, but good quality. A great night out.

title_review: So very good, we went twice !
review_preview: We first went for a late lunch, and returned two nights later for dinner.  Both occcasions came with excellent service and food. We were greeted by the owner warmly. We have never tasted such wonderful and simply prepared tomatoes (twice). Also at lunch, we had...
review_full: We first went for a late lunch, and returned two nights later for dinner. Both occcasions came with excellent service and food. We were greeted by the owner warmly. We have never tasted such wonderful and simply prepared tomatoes (twice). Also at lunch, we had a great salmon/lox sandwich on fresh bread with just some oil. Their olives were also great twice too. The grilled squid was also simple and plainly damn good. We also happened to see the owner at our hotel (Palacio de Ritiro) later that day and told him that we very much enjoyed his food and hospitality. We also said that if we lived in Madrid, we would live at his restaurant. The hotel staff said that we were lucky since he had just reopened from his summer vacation We returned to his restaurant for dinner and had more tomatoes, Iberico ham of which my wife ate and loved too (and she does not like meat), and various grilled mushrooms and seared sushi grade tuna, various cheeses including a burrata, and finished with homemade ice cream and chocolate tart/cake.

title_review: Good value if eating at the counter area
review_preview: If you have a craving to eat mid range Argentinian steak at a reasonable price in central Madrid, this will be the place. The caveat is that you will need to sit at the counter area like the locals do and order the food there....
review_full: If you have a craving to eat mid range Argentinian steak at a reasonable price in central Madrid, this will be the place. The caveat is that you will need to sit at the counter area like the locals do and order the food there. In this area, you get a choice of 3 menus of ‚Ç¨10 to ‚Ç¨13.50 which comes with the type of sausage, steak, dessert, salad/fries and wine. Taking the basic ‚Ç¨10 to ‚Ç¨13.50 menu, this is excellent value and still fee the vice of a typical tapa like bar. The higher the set menu price, the better the cut of the steak. However, if you wish to get rib eye or sirloin steak, you have to take table service where the price doubles and the food item you order that comes exactly from the same menu cost 2-3 times more.  The cuts at the set menu are not great and is mediocre . But if you crave for typical steak and meat menu at a cheap price- this is excellent value.

title_review: A great restaurant for carnivores - with some nice touches!
review_preview: I was taking my cousin and his 14-year-old daughter for dinner while staying in Madrid and she wanted steak, so my cousin chose this Argentinian restaurant just a couple of blocks from Sol. The decor is fresh and our waitress was very friendly, if a...
review_full: I was taking my cousin and his 14-year-old daughter for dinner while staying in Madrid and she wanted steak, so my cousin chose this Argentinian restaurant just a couple of blocks from Sol. The decor is fresh and our waitress was very friendly, if a bit forgetful - I had to ask twice for water and extra cutlery. It was a Sunday night and not terribly busy, but the atmosphere was still good. After seating us we (not my cousin's daughter!) were served complimentary fizzy pink wine, and once the waitress had taken our orders she brought us small glasses of gazpacho. We shared two starter dishes - both very tasty, and hence our need for extra cutlery - and had the sliced steak for three as our main. This was cooked to perfection for all of our tastes (the blue side of rare) and came with fries. We all chose different desserts, and again each got a small, complimentary chocolate mousse. These unexpected extras are a nice touch, but left me feeling very full! There was an extensive wine list, but the waitress wasn't really able to help us choose. I therefore chose a mid-priced bottle of red which turned out to be very good. This was a brilliant choice for my cousin's daughter, who loved it all, and would also suit any hard-core carnivore! It was a little on the expensive side by Madrid standards and my personal preference is for more characterful restaurants serving traditional Spanish regional cuisines.

review_preview: My friend and I recently arrived in Madrid after spending many years in Argentina. We missed the wonderful beef of that country so sought out an Argentine restaurant here. We were not disappointed! The steak was exactly like those eaten on many occasions in Buenos...
review_full: My friend and I recently arrived in Madrid after spending many years in Argentina. We missed the wonderful beef of that country so sought out an Argentine restaurant here. We were not disappointed! The steak was exactly like those eaten on many occasions in Buenos Aires; tender, tasty and cooked to perfection. It was accompanied by an excellent well known Malbec and first rate service. The price was higher than in Argentina (obviously) but included freebies such as a complimentary glass of cava on arrival, a tasty pumpkin soup, chocolate mousse and cava sorbet. If you're looking for steak this is the place to go!

review_preview: I went here in September with my girlfriend and I would say this is probably the best restaurant experience I've had. It was just around the corner from where we were staying so thought why not. We got there before they were doing the evening...
review_full: I went here in September with my girlfriend and I would say this is probably the best restaurant experience I've had. It was just around the corner from where we were staying so thought why not. We got there before they were doing the evening dinner menu so we ordered some starters. We ordered some bread and some dips and as far as bread goes, it's the nicest bread i've ever had! I can't remember what my girlfriend ordered but I got tofu with rice noodles and Hoi Sin and plum saucem which I've tried to recreate so many times since i've come back home but it could never be as nice. The place had a warm atmosphere and we sat at the front of the restaurant where it was open to the cobbly back back road we were on. It seemed like we were in a arty, creative quarter, some people would say it may have looked a bit dark and dangerous around there, I'd say it was similar to the Brick Lane area of London. It's probably the one place that has stuck in my mind and my only regret is we didn't go back again!

review_preview: I found Garcia de la Navarra via our hotel concierge and confirmed it via TripAdvisor. What impressed me the most about the TA reviews was the number of people saying that they returned for a second meal. Given the excellent alternatives in the area I...
review_full: I found Garcia de la Navarra via our hotel concierge and confirmed it via TripAdvisor. What impressed me the most about the TA reviews was the number of people saying that they returned for a second meal. Given the excellent alternatives in the area I was curious to find out why. The food is good, even very good, but it was the service from the owner to the waiters that brought us back a second time as well. We felt like (linguistically challenged) locals by the time we left the first time and like family the second time. They open at 8:30pm but almost no one shows up before 9:00pm. But the early bird snags seats at the bar even when the restaurant is fully booked for the evening. Highly recommended!

review_preview: We were invited here for lunch to celebrate a birthday. It¬¥s a busy modern restaurant in a street on the side of the former 'Palacio de Comunicaciones' turned city hall and you need to book.6 of us shared three first courses 'tapas-style'; melt-in-mouth 'croquetas'...
review_full: We were invited here for lunch to celebrate a birthday. It¬¥s a busy modern restaurant in a street on the side of the former 'Palacio de Comunicaciones' turned city hall and you need to book. 6 of us shared three first courses 'tapas-style'; melt-in-mouth 'croquetas' (one ham, one truffle and the latter really did taste of truffle); a delicious mix of 4 different wild mushrooms and pisto manchego (Spanish ratatouille). They specialise in fresh green veg and there's quite a selection off-menu.  We each chose our own main course. My grilled sole was excellent. We shared three desserts and a bottle of very good Ribera del Duero. I didn't see the bill, but the prices on the menu looked reasonable and it was a great meal and 'sobremesa'.

review_preview: I visited this restaurant on 3rd May with my family as it was recommended by a good friend.  We actually made the reservation whilst passing the previous day, and spoke to a gentleman who was clearly senior - Owner or Manager; to check that he...
review_full: I visited this restaurant on 3rd May with my family as it was recommended by a good friend. We actually made the reservation whilst passing the previous day, and spoke to a gentleman who was clearly senior - Owner or Manager; to check that he could cater for my daughter who has a lactose intolerance. I had also made sure that we carried a card specifically explaining her lactose intolerance - translated into Spanish to avoid confusion. The gentleman who took our booking promised he could provide a good dinner without lactose for may daughter, so we made the booking. When we arrived and were shown to our table we again showed the waitress the card explaining that my daughter has lactose intolerance. She read the card and then really was not interested. When we checked that our order (Argentinian Grill) was completely lactose free (Sin Lactosa) she rudely told us it is meat - no lactose. I asked about the sausages in the grill - again she said it is meat, no milk. I asked her to check with the chef since I know that Chorizo does have milk in it, she again said it is meat, but said she would ask. She came back very quickly to advise us that it was all safe, so we took her at her word. Her service throughout was rude, even pushing my brother-in-law to make room for the wine cooler.  When the food came it was pretty poor - meat was extremely rare - we were not asked how we liked it. Service remained poor. During the night my daughter became very sick and knew that she had ingested lactose.  The next day we visited the restaurant again to complain, and again met the gentleman who took our booking. He remembered out requirement for lastose free meal, and even showed us his menu with allergy information, where it clearly stated that this menu item contain milk. Although he was apologetic, the damage was done. His staff should have offered us the allergy menu, or at least referred to it. I would not recommend this restaurant to any body. If the staff are too lazy and rude to check for food allergies, and can't be bothered to ask for cooking preferences then they do not deserve to have a job in a restaurant.

review_preview: We decided to try this restaurant on our last night in Madrid on the strength of the reviews on here & we were very glad we did!A few people have commented that the waiting staff's English isn't that good & I would agree, but...
review_full: We decided to try this restaurant on our last night in Madrid on the strength of the reviews on here & we were very glad we did! A few people have commented that the waiting staff's English isn't that good & I would agree, but you're in Spain! We both had the fillet steak and I can say it was, without doubt, the best steak we've ever had and we've had our fare share of Scottish and Irish steak! Yes, dinner is served on bamboo plates, with only a bamboo stick as 'cutlery', but that didn't matter a bit, as the food was superb! To be honest, I'm not sure there's room for a dishwasher in the place! (the plates / bamboo sticks are all recycled) As we were nearing the end of our meal, the owner of the restaurant came to ask how our meal was - what a lovely, lovely man! He sat with us, giving us his history and the background to the restaurant (the name Bayres is a combination of Buenos and Aires!). Although he wouldn't admit it, his English is good! He has been importing beef to Spain from Argentina for 25 years, so he certainly knows his stuff! After chatting for quite a while, he disappeared down to the basement and re-appeared with a bottle of Polish vodka (he was born in Poland, before moving to Argentina, before moving to Spain!) and proceeded to have a couple of shots with us!  So, while the food was amazing, the host himself made this visit even more special for us. This is definitely a restaurant we want to return to! Thank you!!

review_preview: My boyfriend and I went twice while we were staying in Madrid. I can honestly say, hands down, that that was the best fillet I have ever had in my life. They don't really speak English, but even though we went there a bit late...
review_full: My boyfriend and I went twice while we were staying in Madrid. I can honestly say, hands down, that that was the best fillet I have ever had in my life. They don't really speak English, but even though we went there a bit late (around 10.30ish) the waiter prepared a table for us and the food was served quickly. We ordered sirloin and fillet tapas the first time, and a maxi fillet cooked (perfectly) to medium rare the second time. If you are a meat lover, Bayres Beef is DEFINITELY your one stop place for meat tapas! Their sangria is really good too.

We will not rush back, it was ok but there are much better restaurants nearby.

title_review: Excellent food, unpretentious and very good service
review_preview: We usually go, at least once a month, to this restaurant and its twin tavern "La Taberna de Pedro". They are in a very central area of ‚Äã‚ÄãMadrid (in the back of Cibeles), in a short street but with excellent restaurants. It is homemade traditional...
review_full: We usually go, at least once a month, to this restaurant and its twin tavern "La Taberna de Pedro". They are in a very central area of ‚Äã‚ÄãMadrid (in the back of Cibeles), in a short street but with excellent restaurants. It is homemade traditional North Spanish cooking, with an excellent quality of seasonal ingredients and a simple and careful preparation. Vegetables are exceptional and fresh: for example, they have a tomato salad that is nothing more than the most incredible of tomatoes (I do not know where they get it from but then no tomato tastes like anything), and a salad of beans green with foie that is absolutely fantastic; artichokes are also exceptional. Gorgeous meats and fish, but the homemade stews are something unique: meatballs, tripe, sometimes they cooked battered chard, etc., all of them really fantastic. The egg dishes and the croquettes are fantastic (the eggs with Burgos black pudding are absolutely incredible). I have to congratulate the restaurant because they have half portions of some dishes, which allows us to try more dishes. For dessert - all of them homemade - they have a really good panchineta. The wine selection is careful and varied - we usually accept the recommendations because they always surprise us. There are not many tables (some high in the entrance, and the bar is always full) and there is always a reservation, at noon or at night. The service is fast, efficient and very friendly. Now they have the terrace open, although with the awnings because the time is still not very safe.

title_review: BEEF HOW IT'S SUPPOSED TO BE
review_preview: We are here on our first night in Madrid. Food: I ordered the max slice sirloin. Beef was succulent, moist and tender. Grilled with a little sea salt accompanied by fresh chimichurri. That's all it needed. And to think it was a sirloin cut which...
review_full: We are here on our first night in Madrid.  Food: I ordered the max slice sirloin. Beef was succulent, moist and tender. Grilled with a little sea salt accompanied by fresh chimichurri. That's all it needed. And to think it was a sirloin cut which in America is the medium grade. Best sirloin I've ever had. It was accompanied with some mozzarella and cherry tomatoes with Argentinian style bread as a vehicle for your meat.  Drink: the Sangria lasted only 5 minutes. Red wine with soda. That good.  Service: Safi was great. I asked him about the meat and he explained as best he could in English. Regardless I got the idea of what he was trying to say. Open field cows raised in Argentina. I gave the chef a thumbs up as a compliment to how good the meat was. At the end of our meal, unexpectedly, Safi gave us both a shot of a cream liquor. Very baileys like. Really great staff there.  When in Madrid, stop by! It's small so you may miss it. But if you do happen to find it, enjoy. I sure did.

title_review: King of the steak sandwiches but poor service
review_preview: In my holiday in Madrid, reviews often overestimated the real value of a restaurant.Bayres was the exception to the rule as it turned to be the best meat restaurant in Madrid!I went there for an early dinner and the service was honestly quite...
review_full: In my holiday in Madrid, reviews often overestimated the real value of a restaurant. Bayres was the exception to the rule as it turned to be the best meat restaurant in Madrid! I went there for an early dinner and the service was honestly quite poor. Tables were barely cleaned up and only essential crockeries and spices were available. The waiter spoke a limited English but he understood my order but never seemed interested in giving a decent service, actually quite annoyed I was the only customer ordering in the first hour of the dinner time. On the contrary, food was amazing. Seriously, tasty and well cooked, the starter with a sausage sandwich was ideal, no wonder I finished in a few minutes! As a main, I ordered a steak, served with chimichurri but also cherry tomato and mozzarella (like the sandwich). Again, something to die for, cooked rare-medium as advised. Prices are very low for the quality of the meat and you can easily order 2 sandwiches and a steak if you are really hungry, without risking to pay more than EUR 20! Service must be more professional (the owner actually seemed very kind asking me if I was happy with the meal in the end) because it was amateurish,even a bit unpolite.

review_preview: We ate here upon the recommendation of our hotel.  The restaurant is small, tucked in behind the bar which faces the street.  After the waiter explained the specials, we decided on the 5-course menu for 2, which included a couple of the specials. When we...
review_full: We ate here upon the recommendation of our hotel. The restaurant is small, tucked in behind the bar which faces the street. After the waiter explained the specials, we decided on the 5-course menu for 2, which included a couple of the specials. When we asked the waiter for wine suggestions to pair with the menu, he suggested that we trust him to give us a small glass of an appropriate wine for each course.   We started with a glass of cava from Muga winery in the Rioja, which we had just visited the day before. Then with the first course of luscious ripe tomatoes and Parmesan cheese, we were served a nice vegetal white Spanish wine. This was followed by two more full-bodied whites with the next courses: baby artichokes, wonderful ham and mushroom croquettes, and perfectly cooked sea bass. The final course was a delectable dish of grilled Iberian pork, also perfectly cooked, accompanied by a full-bodied red. I wish I had written down the names of the wines (all were Spanish), but alas I didn't.  This was perhaps the best meal we have had during our trip in Spain, and we have had quite a few excellent ones. We would definitely be back if we were spending a longer time in Madrid.

review_preview: If you want to convert a vegetarian, this is the place to do it. We were in Madrid for four days, and we came here twice. There are not many restaurants in the world that we have gone back to twice. The chorizo as well...
review_full: If you want to convert a vegetarian, this is the place to do it. We were in Madrid for four days, and we came here twice. There are not many restaurants in the world that we have gone back to twice. The chorizo as well as several various cuts of beef. Most people would assume the tenderloin or rib eye would be the best, however this was not the case. No doubt the tenderloin and rib eye were unbelievably and succulent, we found that the best was actually the skirt steak. I know, I know, that's an odd choice and is clearly a cheaper cut of meat, but you have to listen to me on this one. The skirt steak was not only tender, but packed full of proper beef flavour, the nutty deep flavour that you get in well aged beef (although I am not sure if this is aged at all). The chorizo was also amazing, as was the chimichurri sauce it was served with. The potatoes were also amazing. If I recall correctly, they charge 10 euros for 1.5 L of sangria. Most places charge that for 1 L of sangria. So that's a plus for sure.  I have been to Kobe, Japan and have eaten A4 grade wagyu beef (A5 being the highest). While that was undeniably delicious, I would say the experience I had at Bayers was comparable. While the meat they serve is not as tender as the rediculous marbling of wagyu beef, the skirt steak was just a wave of beef flavour.  If you get the chance to swing by here I would highly recommend it. I would also recommend Taberna del Chato which is just a stone throws away. Heck, since this is Spain, go to both in one day.

review_preview: Our friends recommended a couple other great restaurants earlier in the week that were fantastic.  We asked our hotel concierge for a similar one nearby.  She recommended Garcia de la Navarra.  When we arrived, we should have walked out. It was empty at 10 pm...
review_full: Our friends recommended a couple other great restaurants earlier in the week that were fantastic. We asked our hotel concierge for a similar one nearby. She recommended Garcia de la Navarra.  When we arrived, we should have walked out. It was empty at 10 pm (which unlike the USA is prime time in Spain). The Head Waiter came and bombarded us with specials, then drinks and brought us bread and bottled water (none of which we had ordered). Earlier we had a big 2+ hour lunch so we were really just looking for a light supper. Our instincts after the head waiter's greeting was again to run.  My wife and I both asked several questions about some of the items and the menu itself and it seems even the prices on the menu were just suggestions and the specials were very vague.  We thought that the first course that arrived were supposed to be part of our main course. We did not want appetizers. They were not of course. We were charged 16 Euros for a small plate of plain green beans (no hammer tuna) and 12 Euros for a plate of tomatoes plus 5.6 Euros for bread we did not order and 6 Euros for water we did not order.  In all, we were charged almost 100 Euro for a quick supper.  Having said all that, the food itself was quite good but save yourself the aggravation of the bill and go somewhere else.

review_preview: I had a delicious lunch men√∫ del d√≠a at Vega while visiting Madrid! I recommend everyone to put this stop on their itinerary. It was a comfy, central spot. I dined solo, and was seated at a large communal table for solo diners. It was...
review_full: I had a delicious lunch men√∫ del d√≠a at Vega while visiting Madrid! I recommend everyone to put this stop on their itinerary. It was a comfy, central spot. I dined solo, and was seated at a large communal table for solo diners. It was nice because I got to strike up conversation with others.  It seems their menu is always changing. The lunch special I had was a small white bean and seaweed salad, jackfruit pasta salad, chickpea and mushroom stew, and vegan Nutella cake. The whole meal was so delicious and filling, and only cost 12 euros! (Did I mention a small beer was included in that, to boot?) There‚Äôs even a cheaper option if you want only one main dish, but I couldn‚Äôt pass up filling up on these flavors. Great food, great setting, great deals. I can‚Äôt recommend it enough.

title_review: Buzzing atmosphere with delicious vegan food
review_preview: Another wonderful HappyApp find. We had no idea what to expect and arrived to find the restaurant almost full. We sat at one of the high tables along the door-side wall on bar stools. Not the most comfortable way to dine, but certainly worth the...
review_full: Another wonderful HappyApp find. We had no idea what to expect and arrived to find the restaurant almost full. We sat at one of the high tables along the door-side wall on bar stools. Not the most comfortable way to dine, but certainly worth the slight inconvenience. If you're unlucky enough to arrive when the restaurant has no more space left, you'll be asked to wait. And that'll mean outside if the bar area is also full. The waiters work extremely hard in a small space fielding query after query about availability while serving the tables. Quite a few have been crammed into a not very sizable space and lone diners share a communal table. It was great to see strangers striking up animated conversations while enjoying some of the best vegan food in Madrid. We'll certainly be back for more. And the puddings were scrummy.

The staff here are also very helpful and friendly which just adds to the experience. If you love steak and are in Madrid you must try to go

All in all, a great experience- totally surprising, considering we just wanted a nice plate of pasta.  Definitely on my recommend list !

title_review: Incredible gem of a place in lovely Madrid.
review_preview: We went by as a direct result of reading reviews on this place and certainly was not disappointed. It's tucked away in an unassuming location, and is quite small, but what it lacked in space it more than made up for in food and service....
review_full: We went by as a direct result of reading reviews on this place and certainly was not disappointed. It's tucked away in an unassuming location, and is quite small, but what it lacked in space it more than made up for in food and service. Not all the waiters spoke great English but were incredibly friendly and very accommodating. We ordered a couple drinks each and then went with the "Duo" menu item which is essentially a sampler with 2 sausages and all 4 different cuts of beef. Man was it all ridiculously tasty. By far the filet was the star of the show but the sirloin also more than held its own. The sausage was in fact way better than expected, perfectly seasoned and cooked. Like many others, they offered us free shots towards the end of our meal which we gladly accepted. This was the best meal we had on our week and a half trip to England and Spain and one of the cheaper ones no less.

review_preview: - Firsy surprise: when entering, you'd expect a small bar serving grill dishes. But in the end of the bar, you actually enter in a classy-lovely restaurant, which seems very busy at Tuesday night 11pm.-Second surprise: the waiter offers menu in English and Spanish...
review_full: - Firsy surprise: when entering, you'd expect a small bar serving grill dishes. But in the end of the bar, you actually enter in a classy-lovely restaurant, which seems very busy at Tuesday night 11pm. -Second surprise: the waiter offers menu in English and Spanish *just in case*, and while we are picking the dinner, he is back with 2 welcome drinks. - Third surprise: As said the place was quite full, so we expected to wait long for tge Parilla (Grill) Plate for 2. But in 2 minutes these worries were gone, when were served with generous amuse bouche (bread w cream cheese, chimichurri and a paprika salad, pumpkin soup, grissini). As we finished, soon came the dinner. - Forth surprise: the Parilla was very delicious and more than enough for the 2 of us. It was served with a bottle of nice Spanish wine. All this for a very reasonable price! Overall, attentive and quick service, nice atmosphere and great meat! Worth a visit!

title_review: So why eat Argentinian in Madrid?
review_preview: I eat one steak per year.  Argentinian beef is one of the best.  This restaurant was located on Madrid's Opera Square and was conveniently located to my hotel.  A prie fixe menu of 15 euros provided the following: a starter of either morcilla or fresh...
review_full: I eat one steak per year. Argentinian beef is one of the best. This restaurant was located on Madrid's Opera Square and was conveniently located to my hotel. A prie fixe menu of 15 euros provided the following: a starter of either morcilla or fresh chorizo (I chose morcilla and was delighted), a salad, bread, an expertly grilled entrana steak (skirt steak), cooked by a 20-something who handled the grill like a pro. Dessert was included - I chose a panna cotta with berry sauce (delicious). My young waiter, with a twinkle in his eye, then poured me a shot of crema de guina, a cherry-anise liqueur from Asturias that was most interesting. My steak was cooked rare, per my instruction and the service was attentive. I also had lunch here on another day (a spinach salad with shrimp, fresh mozzarella and walnuts, dressed with oil and vinegar). Prices are fair and the wine and beer are delicious.  I rarely see Argentinian beef at home and decided to try it. Quite happy that I did. For my Spanish friends, I did eat authentically Spanish food in many other places. Look for my review of Galopin, just off the Gran Via, for an intimate Asturias experience.

review_preview: What can we say. Absolutely fantastic. There are two guys that run it, who are the most down to earth, nicest guys you would meet. We were treated like family here and what's more, the food is phenomenal. We went for an evening and had...

We were treated like family here and what's more, the food is phenomenal. We went for an evening and had three steaks, two jacket potatoes, countless olives and crisps, 2 beers and 2 wines which came to 47 euro. Could not believe such quality was so cheap. Would easily pay double that price and not bat an eyelid. We also loved the little touch of plates made of sugar cane and toothpicks for eating. So amazing we went back the next day for lunch. Cannot praise this place enough. A must if in madrid and want steak!!

review_preview: After living in Spain for the past 2 years, we wanted to find a place to eat that was a bit different from the " typical Spanish " cuisine but just as good,  taste, and health wise as the Mediterranean diet is for you.  We...
review_full: After living in Spain for the past 2 years, we wanted to find a place to eat that was a bit different from the " typical Spanish " cuisine but just as good, taste, and health wise as the Mediterranean diet is for you. We certainly found that with Bayres beef and more besides. Bayres beef serves some of the best Argentinian beef I have ever tasted. The meat was beautifully tender and cooked to perfection ( we asked for it medium ) and the accompaniments were just as delicious. The baked potato was devoured in seconds and the cherry tomatoes and mozzarella skewers were a treat. My youngest, who is a terrible eater, had no issues with any of the food and enjoyed a plate of chorizo sausage all to herself.  All the staff were happy to chat and were more than patient with me when I tried to practise my Spanish ( badly) on them. The staff and the owner made the whole experience even more enjoyable by their attentiveness and friendliness to my family.  The greatest surprise came at the end of the evening when we got the bill. As this is a restaurant in the heart of Madrid, I would have expected to pay a small fortune for the amount we had to eat and drink, but the bill came to well under 100 euros, and I mean well under!  I would recommend this place to all types of people on all types of visits. I will definitely be visiting again.  Gracias

title_review: Not your typical place to eat.  It was quite special
review_preview: We had walked by this place at lunch time but did not stop so we came for dinner.  What a wonderful decision.  Warmly greeted and sat outside.  They immediately bring you a glass of Cava, toast with a cheese spread and a small glass of...
review_full: We had walked by this place at lunch time but did not stop so we came for dinner. What a wonderful decision. Warmly greeted and sat outside. They immediately bring you a glass of Cava, toast with a cheese spread and a small glass of gazpacho. All quite tasty. Nice menu leaning towards meat. Large salads and main courses. Excellent service. Don't order dessert as they will bring you all kinds of tasty dessert items anyway along with their own "after dinner drinks". It was my wife's birthday and the waiter brought a nice cheesecake with a candle. It was great having all those dining with us sing Happy Birthday to her in Spanish. A lovely night with lots of laughs and good cheer.

review_full: We searched for veggie places to eat when on holiday and found this place, located on a narrow run down side street near Gran Via. It is small, singularly bare, very run down looking ( deliberately done that way I think ). Ordinary chairs and tables, poorly finished walls , no decorations, one would think even seedy looking. We were rather concerned about how poor it looked, even wondering whether to go in or not. But the temptation of veggie food and hunger made us enter. The place was sparsely occupied, and we were promptly attended to by an unconventional looking young man who was very pleasant and bubbly. He frankly said it was too early for dinner and they only had a few appetisers to offer and we decided to brave it. We ordered a cucumber starter with some spice added to it, and a beetroot hummous ( first time in my life i have heard of such a thing LOL ! ) and a almonds with paprika. Also ordered a beer The beetroot hummous was out of this world, deliciously done, smooth, very tasty. The almonds were crisp roasted and dusted with paprika and just very crunchable. The cucumbers were watery and relatively tasteless . I also had a pumpkin and ginger cream soup , the soup itself was excellent though I did not get much ginger from it. Throughout , the gentleman who attended to us was very interesting and quirkily so, full of bounce and joy and a pleasure to chat to. Worth visiting for a proper meal

review_preview: We came here on our first night in Madrid and I was starving. Like to the point where I thought I was going to be sick kind of hungry! Due to this I thought I wouldn't be able to eat much but as soon as...
review_full: We came here on our first night in Madrid and I was starving. Like to the point where I thought I was going to be sick kind of hungry! Due to this I thought I wouldn't be able to eat much but as soon as the food came and I took the first bite I could not eat it fast enough! They offer you a bowl of chips while you wait. We ordered the Duo platter, which has two sausages, rump, sirloin, and fillet steak, so you can try all of their cuts. They cooked it to perfection (truly medium rare, not what many places give you where it's just slightly pink inside and they call it medium rare) and seasoned it just right. They serve it with skewers (2) of a single cherry tomato and a small boccaccini ball as well as bread and an awesome chimichurri sauce (seeing as it is an Argentinian beef restaurant) The two of us quickly devoured the whole thing, it was so tasty! If you are a true steak lover you must come here, you won't be disappointed!! And when the bill comes, you get a free shot of a Bailey's-type liqueur. Very nice! Also, they use thick paper plates instead of porcelain and no utensils, just wooden skewers to pick up your meat (as it's cut into bite-sized strips). So if you're looking for a fork and knife you'll have to ask (and that's if they have them!)

review_full: Booked after reading the TripAdvisor reviews. The restaurant is located between the Gran Via and Puerta del Sol, so close to all the action. The entrance is the bar area with the dining located through a double door to the rear. Surprisingly, the dining area was very bright, spacious and cheery, helped by mirrors at the end of the room. There are loads of photos of celebrities on the walls around the room; I didn't recognise very many! Service was smart and efficient. First there's a welcome via a glass of cava. The food was truly superb, including one of the best steaks I have ever. The recommended wine was a perfect accompaniment, at just over ‚Ç¨20 for the bottle. We had a asparagus, roasted peppers and chips too. We didn't really want the free mousse dessert and liqueur but we finished them off anyway. Would totally recommend this restaurant and would consider coming back when we return to Madrid, even though there are so many excellent new places to try.

title_review: The place to go for food. Plain and simple
review_preview: I liked it so much that we had dinner, lunch and dinner again. Very friendly place. The owner Wei, is a true professional of the catering trade and certainly knows how to look after its guests. He even kept checking with us if our cars...
review_full: I liked it so much that we had dinner, lunch and dinner again.  Very friendly place. The owner Wei, is a true professional of the catering trade and certainly knows how to look after its guests. He even kept checking with us if our cars were still ok with time on the meeter.  Food, very fresh. Cook to order with any changes wished (and we had people with demands :). Constant attention at the table by multiple waiters and a good selection of wine.  On business, and otherwise, I look for a restaurant with a good level of cleanliness (loos, dining rooms, utensils), Good food made fresh to order. Attentive and friendly staff that knows the menu and their kitchen inside out, good selection of wine and a detail at the end of the meal.  For this, I don't mind paying money (although it was not expensive!) This place meets and surpass my expectations. They don't have 6 stars.

title_review: Excellent menu de dia for dinner
review_preview: This is a charming restaurant very close to the Ruben Dario metro stop.  It combines the urbane and the rustic for great bistro atmosphere.  Service was excellent.  The waiter directed us to the menu of the day for dinner (about 18 euros apiece, plus wine...
review_full: This is a charming restaurant very close to the Ruben Dario metro stop. It combines the urbane and the rustic for great bistro atmosphere. Service was excellent. The waiter directed us to the menu of the day for dinner (about 18 euros apiece, plus wine and mineral water "con gas." I had pastel con verduras--a terrific vegetable terrine; my husband's salad featured endive, radicchio, black olives, etc. For the second course, he had the best salmon he could ever remember (and we lived in Seattle for many years!). My beef medallions in roquefort cream were ok, but nothing like that salmon. For dessert, we had lemon sorbet in cava--think sorbet whipped with champagne. It is a favorite in Madrid, and should be tried at least once. Highlights of the a la carte menu include suckling pig, hake with almonds and ham, and oxtail stew "in the style of El Alino." We plan to return to this restaurant.

review_preview: If we hadn't heard from friends that there was an attractive dining room with good food and service behind the front bar area of EL GAUCHO, we probably wouldn't have bothered to take a look for ourselves. Having done so, however, we are very glad...
review_full: If we hadn't heard from friends that there was an attractive dining room with good food and service behind the front bar area of EL GAUCHO, we probably wouldn't have bothered to take a look for ourselves. Having done so, however, we are very glad we did! The dining room was nicely appointed, the jazz playing softly on the music system nice to listen to and the service immediate and professional. Another Trip Adviser diner complained that there was a "table service and bread" charge, and while we also found that unusual, we didn't find it excessive and we were delighted to have several free surprises brought to the table. It started with a refreshing and well-chilled glass of pink cava, followed by two small glasses of a very nice soup plus toasts, and at the end a cup of chocolate mousse and a sorbet. My wife's Caesar Salad was excellent, as was my salmon-filled pasta in shrimp sauce. We are very pleased to recommend El Gaucho to anyone looking for a good eatery in central Madrid.

review_preview: In my 4 week stay in Madrid, I visited this restaurant 4 times! So you can consider me a big fan.Garcia de la Navarra has everything you want in a restaurant: Great service, fantastic food, tasty wines and just a perfect atmosphere. The quality...
review_full: In my 4 week stay in Madrid, I visited this restaurant 4 times! So you can consider me a big fan. Garcia de la Navarra has everything you want in a restaurant: Great service, fantastic food, tasty wines and just a perfect atmosphere. The quality of the food is of a very high level and the price is just great. Luis and Pedro are great hosts, you feel welcome and appreciated as a customer. The restaurant has a front area where you can sit at high tables or at the bar and enjoy bites, food and drinks. It kind of has a relaxed feeling over it. When you walk further to the back, you can find the restaurant area. The cuisine is always with ingredients of the season. They are non-complicated, but great flavored dishes, for example artichokes, octopus, lamb chops etc. Luis is always there to recommend a fitting wine for the dishes or your taste. Whenever I am back in Madrid, I will always make a reservation at Garcia de la Navarra. It is the hidden-food-gem of Madrid.

review_preview: After many disappointments (of other TripAdvisor top restaurants) that made us question the sophistication of the Spanish cuisine, we found this gem in the most beautiful part of the city. By arriving you can see it is an informal but modern, fresh place - and...
review_full: After many disappointments (of other TripAdvisor top restaurants) that made us question the sophistication of the Spanish cuisine, we found this gem in the most beautiful part of the city. By arriving you can see it is an informal but modern, fresh place - and as you would expect, this translates into superb food. Like Spanish cuisine, it is quite simple, potato croquettes, ham, tomato... But here it works. We had a big tomato with parmesan cheese and oil - amazing dish due to the freshness of the ingredients. The croquettes are to die for - according to the servant the best in Madrid, and we believe him. The drinks are great too, and everything else we tried Not special romantic atmosphere, but if you come for the food, go here - like the locals.

review_full: Only 8.5‚Ç¨ gets you a healthy and filling lunch to power you through sightseeing in Madrid. Location: Don‚Äôt blink or you‚Äôll miss it! On a small quiet street, so a nice break from the hustle and bustle of the city. Seating: Communal tables for solos, small tables for 2 or 4 people. Don‚Äôt worry, there‚Äôs no pressure to interact with your dining mates. You can eat in peace if you want. Service: Great. The place is small so the waitress can see pretty much everyone from anywhere.  Food: Beet soup was creamy and the purple looks fun. You get a purple mustache if you sip. Couscous salad was the main. Fluffy and light, with greens and veggies mixed in. Dessert was a raspberry mousse. So airy! Bread and lemonade were included. (You could get wine or water instead.) Whether you are a vegan or want to try but are fearful of ‚Äúrabbit food,‚Äù try Vega. They will show you to be vegan is anything but bland and your body will thank you for the nutrients.  Plus, you‚Äôll feel better about the churros you‚Äôll eat later (or already have).

I enjoyed the "golden milk" (coconut milk, turmeric and cinnamon I believe) and the beet veggie burger I got. The waiter was a sullen millennial who didn't know squat about the wines he served and was moody and unfriendly, but the food was pretty good. Now, if you want to eat before they open at 8, they will direct you to their other location on Alamo; DON'T GO!!! I mean it. This place was awful. Again, a foolish millennial was the waiter, but the food was worse than bad. I ordered the same drink and they botched it beyond recognition. It had at least 2 TABLESPOONS of powdery turmeric powder in the bottom and tasted like p00p. That's a pretty pricey 5 euro yucky drink. I got the "meatball" dish and it was so salty, I could barely stand it. The onion soup was semi tasty, but again, too much salt! Who ever is overseeing the second restaurant has work to do! Clearly they saw a way to get more money by having a less charming place (looks like a fast food restaurant) open for tourist who want to eat before 8 which is obviously neglected in terms of oversight.

The brother who served us was extremely likeable and unbelievably enthusiastic about his food. We've never found anyone to be so passionate about such simple dishes and it made us savour everything we tasted. The food, service and ambiance made our whole experience there quite memorable and we would certainly recommend it.

Highly recommend this wonderful restaurant.

review_preview: I cannot rave about this place enough. I came on my first night in Madrid with some friends, and loved it so much I came back again on my last night! The first time I shared the antipasti dips, then 4 tapas: the raw lasagne,...
review_full: I cannot rave about this place enough. I came on my first night in Madrid with some friends, and loved it so much I came back again on my last night! The first time I shared the antipasti dips, then 4 tapas: the raw lasagne, the carpaccio, mushrooms croquettes and wedges with Vega sauce, and a cheesecake for dessert. The food was impeccably presented and just so so delicious, I was so impressed. As a vegan who only really goes to vegan restaurants when eating out in different cities, this had to be one of my best experiences! The next time I had the korma curry which was just incredible, so flavoursome and such a good portion size, with bread on the side which was also so delicious. I then had the black forest gateau mousse for dessert which was also so tasty. This place has something for everyone, and the ambiance, food and service were top notch both times I went - can't recommend it enough!

What i really absolutely hated was the fact that everything was served on plastic plates with plastic cutlery and even the salad dressing is in a plastic individual portion. If i'd known any of this before we'd ordered our meal i would have gotten up and left and not let it spoil our night, which it did. The restaurant isn't in a very nice area of Madrid....there's nightclubs surrounding and hawkers trying to get people inside.....a few fights out on the street which i guess were good entertainment. Very very overpriced for what it serves. The tiny tapa sized piece of beef we had i would have expected to be priced as a tapa as with all the previous restaurants we'd been to.....not 11.50. We felt like we were on a plane or having a picnic somewhere....a shame because on the way back there were places with great atmospheres near the restaurant with much better ambience and cheaper prices......i guess you can't always 100% trust tripadvisor unless you read a few of the comments.... The only other things on the menu that were available were beef sandwiches.....and even the guests who were ordering those were sitting there shocked at the poverty size piece of meat on the pieces of bread (and they were locals....LOL).

review_full: We arrived a bit after 4:00 p.m. A very smiley, friendly waitress informed us that the kitchen was closing, but we could have the "menu de la tarde", which contained 6 appetizer options, a few soups, et al. Then, what looked like the owner/manager came to take our order. He wasn't necessarily rude, but seemed a bit standoffish. Somehow he refused to let us order more than three appetizers and a couple of soups. It wouldn't have been bad if the appetizers weren't minuscule, all three came literally in a little rectangular plate. Don't get me wrong: the food was truly delicious. The soups were the best and actually they came in very generous portions. I would come back for the food and, to be fair, the waitress was very nice. She even helped us get our baby stroller out when it was time to leave. But a few things for everyone to know: this is a very small, simple place. You sit in tiny or shared tables or high tables--quite uncomfortable. It reminds me of a few food joints in my home town! Not a place for families with children.

Easy to explain:the owner us from Argentina and has been selling and serving beef for decades. Both dishes we tried, were cooked exactly as ordered, served sliced, with bread on the side. Simple but does not distract from the quality of the meat, and is quite nourishing as a quick lunch or a quick dinner. Friendly and effucient service, the owner was on site when we were there and stopped by each table to say hi. We would recommend a visit if you are in town and if you do not view meat eating as objectionable.

title_review: Not the greatest location, but good Tapas
review_preview: A small hole in the wall joint in the by lanes of Madrid city. It is sandwiched a club and a store and opens out into a very busy, noisy and an overall not so pleasant street. With most of the seating outside, you pretty...
review_full: A small hole in the wall joint in the by lanes of Madrid city. It is sandwiched a club and a store and opens out into a very busy, noisy and an overall not so pleasant street. With most of the seating outside, you pretty much have no choice than to be exposed to the surroundings.  The food was good, but the quantity that you will usually get in a Tapas (small qty). The prices were a tad above average, but I guess serving Argentinian beef could justify the mark-up. All-in-all an average place and nothing to write home about. Not worth a long trip to the restaurant, but if you stumble across it and fancy some beef do visit.

title_review: A hidden gem close to El Museo del Prado
review_preview: We were in search of a restaurant recommended by a travel book near the Prado and found that it was closed.  Across the street was a very small restaurant with only 4 or 5 tables, 2 high tops and 2 stools at a small bar....
review_full: We were in search of a restaurant recommended by a travel book near the Prado and found that it was closed. Across the street was a very small restaurant with only 4 or 5 tables, 2 high tops and 2 stools at a small bar. One table was available, and we took a chance. In 25 days in Spain, it was the best spur of the moment decision we made. A very delightful young woman brought us menus and took our order for drinks. We could see from our table that there was another young woman preparing food in the small kitchen. We ordered "tostas" - half a roll, toasted with a variety of toppings. I had chicken with brie some veggies and an incredible lemon mustard sauce. My wife had smoked salmon. The combination of flavors of each of our dishes was far more sophisticated and delicious than we expected. We could not believe that such a small kitchen and one hard-working chef produced such delectable food. As we watched the chef prepare other orders, we saw how much thought and care went into each dish. Even the presentation was exceptional. Wherever you are in Madrid, this is a gem of a restaurant that you will definitely be grateful you found. (P.S. The pizzas looked absolutely amazing.)

We shared a bruschetta style starter that was really quite tasty. I had a pizza that tasted pretty good and the other half had a creamy pasta dish that was filling and tasty. I remember having a dessert that was yummy, but I can't recall what it was. I'm sure the minutes are now spending times on my hips though!  Definitely worth a stop if you want a fast and tasty bite to eat.

Price-wise, the place was a bargain!  I would definitely return there!

title_review: Affordable tapas with an authentic family vibe
review_preview: Great super small tapas spot! It felt a strong family vibe while dining, all the locals know the owners and kept coming in and saying hello to them. It was like a rotating door. The toast was out of this world! I wasn‚Äôt going to...
review_full: Great super small tapas spot! It felt a strong family vibe while dining, all the locals know the owners and kept coming in and saying hello to them. It was like a rotating door.  The toast was out of this world! I wasn‚Äôt going to get it but I saw a table next to us order and I was curious. It was worth it and affordable. Heavy on the Brie, light balsamic and fresh arugula. The toast was thick and toasted perfect.  I initially came here for the empanadas I ordered a chicken and a beef one. They were baked and had a decent portion of filling but my taste buds gravitated towards the toast.  The wine was decent and affordable, the tables are very small so get ready to be on top of people. We call it the snuggle factor when your eating. I would recommend this location for a tapa experience. Just get ready to be in tight quarters and you will have to speak loudly. All around I had a great experience and would recommend you to visit.

Was in a rush, so opt for the lasagne which beppe claims to be the best one in Madrid. It is special, at least never tasted something like it before. The top part is very soft and the lasagne sheet is thin. Beppe explained that it is prepared the day before and get heated on the spot which is the reason it is quick. The taste is also great. Feel sorry for me that I had not been to this place earlier as it opens from 8:30pm during the evening which is too late for me

title_review: Nice niche restaurant, with a great atmosphere and delicious pizzas
review_preview: We booked through Trip Advisor and when arriving, we were seated immediately at the table of our choice. The staff were smiling, friendly and helpful, as although I was speaking my best Spanish, their English outshone me (hey, when in Rome....!!) and we were able...
review_full: We booked through Trip Advisor and when arriving, we were seated immediately at the table of our choice.  The staff were smiling, friendly and helpful, as although I was speaking my best Spanish, their English outshone me (hey, when in Rome....!!) and we were able to order precisely what we wanted.  The prices were reasonable, the pizzas were not burned, as some can turn out to be and the swift service couldn't be faulted.  To finish off, I had a lovely dessert of profiteroles and chocolate sauce, which were divine.  If you want a simple lunch or dinner and you're nearby when shopping along Calle Gran Via or thereabouts (we came in via their teriffic subway system, from Chueca and had a short walk) you will not be let down by this wonderful pizzeria.

review_full: Looked on TA for an Italian restaurant in Madrid, and booked a table here. If we had not booked but seen it in passing would probably not have gone in. It is very basic and was very busy on Saturday night. The clientele were mainly student age, which was 50 years ago for us. We were balanced on high stools with tables very close on each side. The food however was extremely good. I had an excellent pizza and my wife reported her pasta as equally good. It was a fun place and the very hard working staff were friendly and helpful. Recommended for the food, but not a place for a relaxing romantic dinner. Very good value.

I work in Madrid for 2 of every 4 weeks and have been meaning to try this place everytime I walked by, tonight was the night... and it didnt dissapoint! Excellent food, staff, service and quality. Great setting for all occasions. Managed by a fabulous attentive host. Having had the vegetable Curry Gyozas to start and the Terriyaki chicken for the mains, I was extremely impressed. I have been many times in Tokyo, and this was just as authentic. Fantastic attentive service, and very reasonably priced cuisine. I will for sure be back to this fabulous place. Credit to all the staff and owner... Muchas Gracias!

title_review: Funky Little Restaurant With Awesome Food
review_preview: We really enjoyed our evening at this restaurant. We were staying nearby and this popped up when we were searching for a nice spot for dinner. There was a rather large group of people in one side of the restaurant, plus a few other tables...
review_full: We really enjoyed our evening at this restaurant. We were staying nearby and this popped up when we were searching for a nice spot for dinner. There was a rather large group of people in one side of the restaurant, plus a few other tables taken up. Luckily there was one table with room for all four of us left. The waiter was super friendly and attentive, joking around with us as he took our orders. The sangria was outstanding and they also served some delicious, fresh bread. The bread set the tone for the rest of the meal, everything was great. The menu offers a selection of both tapas and entrees. We never felt neglected because of the large group (which often happens to smaller tables when there is a big party in the same restaurant). I was extremely happy with this restaurant and I liked the rustic decor a lot too.

title_review: Excellent Spanish (and fusion) restaurant near Bernabeu
review_preview: This is an upmarket restaurant with contemporary decor serving Spanish food with a twist - a refreshing variation from the countless traditional Spanish tascas and restaurants all over Madrid. They encourage sharing so the method of serving is similar to a tasting menu.  The menu...
review_full: This is an upmarket restaurant with contemporary decor serving Spanish food with a twist - a refreshing variation from the countless traditional Spanish tascas and restaurants all over Madrid. They encourage sharing so the method of serving is similar to a tasting menu. The menu can be a bit confusing because it consists of starters and main dishes but in the end all dishes are served to share - recommendation is to select 5-7 dishes. The ambiance and service was very good and the waiters were very helpful during the ordering process. Highlights include the ceviche limero (authentic), dumplings rabo de toro (very nice), sui mai, arroz cachufa (delicious fried rice), chili crab, pez mantequilla and albondigas al curry (not exactly standard in a Spanish restaurant) among others. The wine (Raso de Larrainzar from Navarra) really stood out. For desser the cheesecake experiment was exceptionally good as was the torrija. Chupitos went down well as well. The portions are are not large but the serving process ensures you will not go hungry. Five of us spent 230 euros (including 2 bottles of wine that were reasonably priced). Why eat in overly expensive upmarket restaurants in London and Paris when you can come here?

review_preview: Never left any comments of any sort before, but I think that for once, I should share my experience. Having spent two months in Japan, I stopped looking for japanese food in Europe, as I am most of the time bitterly disappointed. My trip to...
review_full: Never left any comments of any sort before, but I think that for once, I should share my experience. Having spent two months in Japan, I stopped looking for japanese food in Europe, as I am most of the time bitterly disappointed. My trip to Madrid has changed my mind. We went to the DokiDoki on a thursday night, quite late I must say, and the restaurant was rather busy. We hadn't to wait for long, though. We appreciated the discret but very attentive service, and the owner's friendly explanations of the menu, patiently repeated in three different languages to my different guests. We had tuna tartare, Misoyaki gindara, nigiris and shared various other dishes all exquisite and amazingly presented. The puddings were to die for, especially the gold coated chocolate fondant. Great setting, minimalist and modern, a very creative atmosphere, outstanding food and top service. Beyond my wildest expectations. Can't wait to come back next summer!

review_preview: This is tiny (only 6 tables) hole-in-the-wall, just off the main street of Calle de la Princesa near the Moncloa Metro stop.  The food is wonderful with lots of flavours from the Sardinian chef and co-owner Beppe.  He and his partner Manuel serve the specialty...
review_full: This is tiny (only 6 tables) hole-in-the-wall, just off the main street of Calle de la Princesa near the Moncloa Metro stop. The food is wonderful with lots of flavours from the Sardinian chef and co-owner Beppe. He and his partner Manuel serve the specialty of Piadina, a type of Italian sandwich or wrap made with what resembles a flour tortilla, but made by Beppe's skilful hands, it is unmistakably Italian! Well worth a try! For lunch I had the Caprese salad made with creamy B√∫falo mozzarella, fresh tomatoes and whole basil leaves! Excellent! Next I had the lasagne with meat, which was also packed with flavour and delicious! The pasta here is cooked to Spanish, not Italian, tastes. So if you want your pasta "al dente" better ask up front as Beppe will prepare it the way it is requested. The service is outstanding, fast and efficient, the food is wonderful and the prices very reasonable -- what more can one ask for?

title_review: The best Japanese food in Madrid!
review_preview: For the past 3 years, I have been missing and craving great Japanese cuisine. Last night, I just found it in this amazing little restaurant. Everything about my experience was fantastic. From the beautiful and very inviting atmosphere, to the extremely friendly staff, and of...
review_full: For the past 3 years, I have been missing and craving great Japanese cuisine. Last night, I just found it in this amazing little restaurant. Everything about my experience was fantastic. From the beautiful and very inviting atmosphere, to the extremely friendly staff, and of course not forgetting the amazing food I had. The owner/manager of the restaurant is extremely knowledgeable about what he's serving his clients, he will take the time to help you decipher the menu and make suggestions. He will even go to great lengths to accommodate your special needs (Allergies and all), always with a smile, and you feel that he loves what he does. From the appetizers to the sweet treats, everything I've tried was delicious. I am definitely going back and sending all my friends and contacts to this wonderful little gem. I highly recommend it!

review_full: Small restaurant with great atmosphere. We ate here twice. First time (lunch) we had pizza with was very nice. Second time (dinner) we made the mistake of having a starter...big portions meant we couldn't finish our main meal. We had the starter "cheese baked in the oven".....if you like cheese you will love this.....melted cheese with fresh bread. Absolutely beautiful. My only criticism would be that the bread was cold & would have been so much nicer had it been warmed through.  Pasta dish for main...big portions of very tasty food. Bottle of house red. Staff boxed what we couldn't eat so we could take it home.  Bill was less than 50 Euro. Highly recommended.

review_preview: Latasia is a lovely, friendly restaurant with amazing food! Sitting from any table you have the view of the workshop-like kitchen where you can see the chefs working. The menu offers a variety of mouth watering starters. We had the chicken croquetas, prawns  and the...
review_full: Latasia is a lovely, friendly restaurant with amazing food! Sitting from any table you have the view of the workshop-like kitchen where you can see the chefs working. The menu offers a variety of mouth watering starters. We had the chicken croquetas, prawns and the ceviche, juicy raw fish, all absolutely exquisite. One of the main course consisted in slow roasted pork and pan fried to finish it.....incredible! We also had the Foie with vanilla snow, nuts and pineapple. It all was followed by delectable dessert. Everything was so fresh and the chefs defenetly take great care in selecting the best quality ingredients. The service is excellent, the waitresses are always smiling and charming. For these reasons I highly recommend going to Latasia restaurant!

review_preview: If you can imagine Spanish cuisine with influences of Peru and Asia, then Latasia is a place you might try.  The setting is friendly and comfortable, but the food is the star.  We started with the seabass in a ceviche broth, which was light and...
review_full: If you can imagine Spanish cuisine with influences of Peru and Asia, then Latasia is a place you might try. The setting is friendly and comfortable, but the food is the star. We started with the seabass in a ceviche broth, which was light and wonderful. The stir-fried sweetbreads were done with a dusting of chili powder, and the effect was amazing. Next came short ribs in a Korean style -- wonderful. The chef spent six years working in Singapore and later in Peru, and these wonderful influences inform his cooking. The wine list is ample and the prices reasonable. Although Spanish is still the operative language, they do have a menu in English that is helpful. We can't wait to go back!

review_preview: Imagine turning up somewhere on a Monday night in July in Madrid and there being no tables? This was our fate. Following a frantic few minutes outside (I had been in the restaurant long enough when asking for the table to know that I absolutely...
review_full: Imagine turning up somewhere on a Monday night in July in Madrid and there being no tables? This was our fate. Following a frantic few minutes outside (I had been in the restaurant long enough when asking for the table to know that I absolutely had to dine there. The smells were captivating. I needed to eat the fusion of passion that is Singaporean, Peruvian and Spanish food). The waiter soon came outside to tell us that a table were leaving and that we could be squeezed in in ten minutes or so. Already 10/10 for the thoughtful waiting staff who could clearly see the distressed look on my face. Quick! Save that girl outside they thought! Upon seating we were treated exceptionally well. The attention to detail is what so many places are trying to achieve but often miss the mark ever so slightly (although sometimes you wonder if they've even been aiming at anything at all). No, we had odd cutlery and funky side plates, but it worked and everything had a purpose. The menu was by no means extensive, but I would have eaten everything on it twice over given the time.  My regret is not ordering the crab...but now I know I must return. We opted for the alitas (deboned chicken wings served in lettuce). These were the perfect kind of spicy, not too much but hit the spot. So flavoursome, I've been thinking about them all week. We also had the tuna steak, bocata de la reina, and the there was the ceviche. Easily the best ceviche I've ever had, and it's something I order a lot. It was this that first drew me to the restaurant and now I know why. Come here and try the ceviche (and a few other things) but the ceviche is a true must. I was with some ceviche unbelievers, and they have been reformed.  Oh, and then there is the world's greatest cheesecake. Just go and order it: if desserts could have start up equivalents, this would be the uber cheesecake. In that, it disrupts everything you ever thought cheesecake should be but now wonder what you did for dessert before this, how you thought a dried digestive base was acceptable when you can have this delight?  And the wine was good too.  So 10 out of 10 for the delicious foods, flavour, waiting staff and for making a Monday night mean something! Now I know I have to book, and I very much will. Until the next time Latasia!

We started with miso soup, had Iberico pork gyozas (yum), shared an Akami roll (red tuna and avocado), unagi and a very special wagyu/truffle sushi that was torched every so slightly. We finished with an amazing dessert - chocolate fondant with raspberry sorbet and cream. Everything was so beautiful and flavorful. Would definitely return! They also have a shop nearby that sells tabletop items.

review_preview: On the basis of the recommendations on Trip Advisor decided to seek out this restaurant. Got there about 1.45pm not long after they had opened for lunch. Even although the restaurant is small to the extent of being poky and not really suitable for pushchairs...
review_full: On the basis of the recommendations on Trip Advisor decided to seek out this restaurant. Got there about 1.45pm not long after they had opened for lunch. Even although the restaurant is small to the extent of being poky and not really suitable for pushchairs they were able to squeeze us in leaving our pushchair next to the table. Alternatively, if it can fold they can look after it for you. Within 45 mins. the place had filled up with both locals and tourists. Restaurant has a good selection of pizzas and pastas with specials chalked up on a blackboard. We ordered a mixed bruschetta appetiser, followed by a Calzone pizza, which was excellent and my wife ordered one of the specials listed on the board which was salmon gnocchi which was equally as good as the pizza. Kids ate a nice olive oil focaccia bread. The staff are are all quite young, Italian (or at least they all speak Italian among themselves) and hip (think tattoos and earrings) and our waiter was friendly and accommodating.  Two days later decided to go back again for lunch but this time the ham and mushroom pizza my wife had was not as good and the lasagne that I ordered was good although not great. Neither was the tiramisu I had for desert - I can't put my finger on it but something was missing. Service second time around although still efficient was not as friendly although this was down to our assigned waitress who seemed rather harassed throughout our visit. Overall good value for money.

title_review: You'll probably have a great experience overall...
review_preview: It's and easy 2 to 3 block walk from the Atocha (not  Atocha Renfe) metro station within an area that seemed safe to wander through at the time we did. You may need to use your phone app to find it quickly. We arrived for...
review_full: It's and easy 2 to 3 block walk from the Atocha (not Atocha Renfe) metro station within an area that seemed safe to wander through at the time we did. You may need to use your phone app to find it quickly. We arrived for a late lunch circa 15:30 and the place was nearly full and quite busy. It's a somewhat tiny space inside and we were fortunate to get the last rickety small table against the back wall. The wooden chairs seemed less than stable and were not the most comfortable, but we lost our concerns and ignored how warm it was in there within a few minutes of getting into our chilled bottle of albarino which was better than very good and of moderate priced. Our waiter was pleasant and nonintrusive. Despite somewhat cramped conditions and the hot afternoon, the place had a friendly feel to it and everyone appeared content in this local ambiance. I wouldn't exactly call this a tapas bar, but with great wine flowing through a circulatory system, any normal person wouldn't debate what to call the food. Several pizza choices were available, but we didn't come to Spain for pizza (perhaps my spouse did) and, thus, we didn't try the pizza. Our "tapas" choices turned out to be truly tasty (tostada de queso de cabra/goat cheese y espinacas/spinach, empanada de queso de cabra y cebolla/onion which was caramelized, and we shared a great ensalada racula/arugula). The table was too small to fit everything (an extra chair was provided that solved that problem), but we left satisfied since the portions were more than good-sized and the total bill was moderate and fair. We prefer another small "hidden gem" we've found in Madrid, but we'll likely return here some day and we do believe the overall experience is worth your visit.

review_full: I went there for an special event/celebration. First, keep in mind it is important to make a reservation... it is usually crowded. I am still not sure about the food. For instance, the waiter recommended us the tuna sashimi with truffle. But if the tuna is good enough (as I am sure it was), why do you want to top it with truffle? It totally kills the fish flavor... same is true if you put black truffle in a small bite of meet or whatever... Honestly, I am not convinced about it. The sashimi is great, but it is too expensive (hard to enjoy while thinking about the price). The best part were the seaweed salad and the maki... very good and at a more reasonable price. However, the star of the show were the the cocktails... The barman was extremely nice, and he explained us the cocktails he prepares. OMG! Perfect drinks that matched extremely well with a fishy meal. Cannot wait to come back for another round of cocktails!!!!

review_preview: While I like to think of myself as an open minded traveller, I must admit to a certain leaning towards Italy. That said, I found this small Trattoria on Calle Hortaleza to be "motto bene".Although it is named the pizza maker, there are any...
review_full: While I like to think of myself as an open minded traveller, I must admit to a certain leaning towards Italy. That said, I found this small Trattoria on Calle Hortaleza to be "motto bene". Although it is named the pizza maker, there are any number of pasta dishes and also nice salads. The pasta is fresh and of the right texture while the sauces are properly crafted. The pies are very good with a thin crust that is dry on the botttom. The sauce and cheese are first rate(for Spain) and the toppings decent. I enjoyed the salad and the drinks, wine, etc were OK. To do better on the pizza you would have to be in Rome at Remo Pizzeria or Phoenix at Bianco. All main dishes were E10-15 and the service was friendly.

title_review: A great authentic Italian restaurant - good quality freshly cooked food
review_preview: A small restaurant which is worth seeking out. The food is freshly cooked and is of a high quality. The costs are also very reasonable e.g. a wonderful pizza at around 9.90 euros. Be aware - the Spanish like to eat late! My son and...
review_full: A small restaurant which is worth seeking out. The food is freshly cooked and is of a high quality. The costs are also very reasonable e.g. a wonderful pizza at around 9.90 euros. Be aware - the Spanish like to eat late! My son and I ate here twice during our Madrid visit. On the first occasion we went to the restaurant at 7pm - it was quiet - there were a couple of other people in the restaurant and also the pasta dishes had not yet been prepared - it was too early! On our second visit, we arrived at 8.30pm and it was more busy (and got even busier whilst we were there). The atmosphere was good and the staff efficient and friendly. If you like pizza or pasta, this is an authentic Italian restaurant serving good quality freshly cooked food.

review_preview: We went here early - when they opened at 8.30pm - and got the only table left, but had to be out by 10pm as the table was booked for then. Our fault, not theirs, as we hadn't booked!We chose Tempura Langoustines, Tempura Vegetables...
review_full: We went here early - when they opened at 8.30pm - and got the only table left, but had to be out by 10pm as the table was booked for then.  Our fault, not theirs, as we hadn't booked! We chose Tempura Langoustines, Tempura Vegetables and a 5 fish Sashimi to share - super choice from a wide and varied menu! Every dish was beautifully and perfectly presented and the Tempura was exceptionally well cooked! The portions are a reasonable size, so we both had ice cream for dessert. Our service was great, considering it was busy, and our Filipino waitress and Spanish waiter were so helpful and attentive. We washed everything down with a lovely bottle of house cava - great value for money! A great Japanese restaurant, lovely food and great service! Will certainly be going back on our next Madrid visit!

review_preview: My wife, my nine year old daughter and I were so fortunate to have had the opportunity to dine here during our trip to Madrid. This is quite possibly the best restaurant that serves "authentic" Italian food. We have visited Italy in the past, so...
review_full: My wife, my nine year old daughter and I were so fortunate to have had the opportunity to dine here during our trip to Madrid. This is quite possibly the best restaurant that serves "authentic" Italian food. We have visited Italy in the past, so we knew as soon as we tasted that first bite, that we were in an Italian heaven! The Chef, Gianni, was simply the most friendly, caring and loving human being! He truly showed personal interest in our satisfaction. It is very refreshing indeed to see the Chef himself be so involved, especially with tourists. I can understand that kind and generous behavior towards locals and/or regulars. But, Gianni made our dining experience absolutely wonderful and enthralling. I would love to suggest some of the F/B items from the menu, but I will say this...anything you try here at this lovely replica of Italian Hospitality, will be a winner.  I am attaching pictures that includes one with our bill, so you can see the menu items that we had. It was simply, heavenly! A special Thank you or may I say, " grazie" to Gianni for his hospitality and graciousness in hosting us so beautifully. God Bless you! Hope to see you soon....God willing! Cheers!
